snippet: The group’s sweep into Mosul and farther south appeared to catch many Iraqi and U.S. officials by surprise, but the gains were the realization of a yearslong strategy of state-building.
abstract: Gains made by Islamic State in Iraq and Syria fighters in their lighting sweep into Mosul, Iraq, and farther south took many by surprise, but were actually realization of yearslong strategy of state-building that militant group itself promoted publicly; examination of group's history through its own documents shows that it had been far more ambitious and effective than United States officials judged.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO, KAREEM FAHIM and BEN HUBBARD
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Erbil, Kareem Fahim from Cairo, and Ben Hubbard from Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The group’s sweep into Mosul and farther south appeared to catch many Iraqi and U.S. officials by surprise, but the gains were the realization of a yearslong strategy of state-building.

headline.main: Rebels’ Fast Strike in Iraq Was Years in the Making
headline.print_headline: Rebels’ Fast Strike in Iraq Was Years in the Making
